thread.title: Leading CEO reveals challenging past

title: Leading CEO reveals challenging past
text:
Thu, Aug 6, 2015, 8:41 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed Leading CEO reveals challenging past AAP – 59 minutes ago 

Alison Watkins knows more than most about the glass ceiling. 
The Coca-Cola Amatil boss says she experienced plenty of challenges during the early and mid 2000s when stepping into chief executive roles, first at fruit juice giant Berri and then at agribusiness GrainCorp. 
"There were some individuals, internally and externally, who thought I wouldn't last long, mostly on the basis of that elusive concept of `she's not a right fit,'" Ms Watkins told a business leaders forum in Brisbane. 
"What they really meant was `not blokey or operational' enough." 
Ms Watkins didn't let that stop her and she credits her experience at the helm of Berri and GrainCorp as key to her appointment as Coca-Cola Amatil managing director in March 2014. 
She is one of only two women currently leading an ASX top 50 company. 
Ms Watkins admits she didn't always have the drive or self-belief to take on such big roles. 
In fact, the Tasmanian had initially dreamt of attending agricultural college and marrying a farmer. 
It was her mother who encouraged her to go to university. 
And since those early days, Ms Watkins has had a handful of male mentors, including her husband Rod, playing a big part in her success. 
Many of them not only gave her a go, but had plenty of faith in her ability, Ms Watkins said. 
"Certainly early on in my career I did need people to give me a shove," she said. 
"My path to leadership has been mostly filled with positive experiences." @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Women jobseekers boost jobless rate AAP
